title: Present Perfect – Form & Use
summary: This lesson explains the form and various uses of the present perfect tense, including experiences, actions with unspecified time, duration, recent events, and contrast with the past simple.
content: The present perfect is formed with 'have/has' + past participle.
We use it for past actions when the time is not mentioned or not important.
Common with adverbs like just, already, yet, recently, never, ever, before.
Used with unfinished time expressions (e.g. today, this week, this year).
Used to express life experiences and superlatives with 'ever'.
Describes how many times something has happened up to now.
Used with 'for', 'since', and 'how long' to show duration from past to present.
'Has gone to' means someone is still away; 'has been to' means someone has returned.
Contrasts with past simple when the specific time is mentioned or asked.

examples.rule: Use the present perfect for actions without mentioning when.
examples: I’ve broken my arm.
I’ve passed the exam.
She’s found a job.

examples.rule: Use 'just', 'already', 'yet' for recent or expected actions.
examples: Tony has just called.
I’ve already finished my homework.
Have you finished your homework yet?
I haven’t finished my homework yet.

examples.rule: Use the present perfect with 'recently' for recent actions.
examples: They’ve recently bought a new car.

examples.rule: Use with unfinished time expressions like 'today', 'this week'.
examples: I’ve seen John today.
Has she called you this week?

examples.rule: Use the present perfect for past experiences with 'never', 'ever', or 'before'.
examples: I’ve never read this book.
Have you ever seen a John Wayne film?
I haven’t experienced anything like this before.

examples.rule: Use with superlatives + 'ever' to express unique experiences.
examples: This is the best meal I’ve ever had.
It’s the most amazing place we’ve ever travelled to.

examples.rule: Use the present perfect to say how many times something has happened.
examples: I’ve watched this film three times.
We’ve been to Paris twice.

examples.rule: 'Has gone to' means still away; 'has been to' means returned.
examples: Tom has gone to Ireland. (=He’s in Ireland now)
We have been to Ireland three times. (=We are not in Ireland now)

examples.rule: Use 'for', 'since', and 'how long' for ongoing actions from the past.
examples: We’ve been married for 25 years.
I’ve had this watch since I was a kid.
How long have you been friends?
I’ve been here for hours.
She’s been my teacher for three years.
I’ve been unemployed since May.
I’ve lived in this town since I was born.

examples.rule: Use 'lately' or 'all + time period' for ongoing recent actions.
examples: She’s been with me all day.
I’ve been very busy lately.

examples.rule: Do not use 'ago' with the present perfect.
examples: ✅ I’ve had my watch for two years.
❌ I’ve had my watch since two years ago.

examples.rule: Use present perfect for unspecified time; past simple for specific time.
examples: I’ve lost my keys.
We’ve been to a very nice restaurant.
We arrived yesterday.
When did the accident happen?

examples.rule: Use past simple for details after a present perfect introduction.
examples: A: I’ve been to the cinema. B: What did you see? A: I saw a very good film.
A: Oh, you’ve broken your arm. B: Yes, I have. A: How did it happen?

tips: Use short forms (’ve, ’s, haven’t), but not in positive short answers.
Use present perfect when time is unknown or not important.
Use past simple when the time is known, asked, or specified.
Don’t use 'ago' with the present perfect.
Use 'for' with durations, 'since' with starting points.
'Has gone to' = still away; 'has been to' = returned.
